Review Title: “Honouring a National Hero: The Elephant Pass Bulldozer Memorial”
Review Text: Our recent visit to the Elephant Pass memorial site, where the terrorist bulldozer was destroyed by Hasalaka Gamini, was a deeply moving and meaningful experience. This place stands as a powerful reminder of courage, sacrifice, and the high price paid for peace in Sri Lanka. Seeing the remains of the bulldozer and learning about the bravery displayed during that historic moment gave us a profound sense of respect and gratitude for the soldiers who defended the nation. The site is simple yet impactful, allowing visitors to reflect quietly on the events that took place. It is well worth visiting for anyone interested in Sri Lankan history, especially those who wish to understand the realities faced during the conflict years. A visit here is not just sightseeing—it is a moment of remembrance and appreciation. Highly recommended for those traveling through Elephant Pass.
Keeps an important place for itself with respect to the civil war. The history behind this place is mind blowing considering one of the recent battles of the 21st century having taken place here.

Review Title: Fascinating historical site and bird watching
Review Text: Fascinating place. Good bird watching. We ate breakfast at the cafe and enjoyed the hstorical backdrop.

A memorial dedicated for one of the greatest ever war heros and the first recepiant of Parama Weera Vibhushaya Copral Gamini Kularatne. Also this is the only place in Sri Lanka where you can clearly witness the sunrise & sunset...
Quite a historic place. Learning the history about how a war once took place here was very interesting. A landmark in the 30 year civil war history of Sri Lanka
I got the feeling climbing up the monument the gravity of the moment, the remembrance of lives lost to bring peace into this land. Do climb!!!

A geographically interesting narrow isthmus which carries the railway and the A9 road into Jaffna and was of strategic importance militarily during the Civil War between the Sri Lankan forces and the Tamil Tigers. As such it has now become a war memorial. There is a small restaurant with reasonable toilets, maintained by the Army. The modernised railway station is nearby. In spite of the name there are no elephants on the pass itself.
Well worth a stop and to spend 30 minutes to read about the national war hero and to visit his memorial to his heroic actions. A true hero fell.
As you pass through, given its importance as the main link between the Jaffna peninsula and the mainland, you are busy clicking away!
The whole A9 experience was amazing.  Elephant pass to me came live after all those years of reading of it and washing it in the news. This place holds significance for the millennials of Sri lanka.
Historical site on the way to Jaffna.  Very well attended by visitors.  Toilets and food stop as well.
One of the memorials remaining from 30 year war held in the area. The place is well maintained and situated next to the Elephant Pass Railway Station.
A good place to visit and can see the history war of SriLanka and all are one has flag and the symbols too
Worth a stop - this memorial is very well presented with an easy sloping access path.  There are toilets here too!

Named thus by the British who brought their elephants up through this area, it is near to where the last big battle for control was fought between the Tamil Tigers and Government troops during the civil war. It is also near to the the armoured bull dozer which threatened to blow up a large number of defenders was halted due to the bravery of one NCO in the Sri Lanka government forces.

I do not encourage to spend time here. It was an space where both Sinhala & Tamile people died in the war time. Sinhala people who go on trips to Jaffna become sad and Tamil people who go for their daily work become angry when they pass Elephant passage.

If you go to Jaffna - which I highly recommend - don't go by bus. Take the midday train from to Jaffna. Don't worry, even the third class is comfortable just find a nice seat and enjoy the view. Everything will be changing around you: from the lush green rainforest to the dark blue waters of the lagoons. From thick jungle vegetation to coconut palms lining the horizon. Finally, as you cross the famous "Elephant Pass" in the late afternoon, the sun slowly sets over the beautiful lagoon and the sky is in flames. Magical.

Recently there has been great renovation work done to this area.  We just traveled though it - its getting there and is going to be a great tourist place.  Even so I noted that people are using the area for their special wedding pictures.  It has a relaxing effect, strange really when you know all the meaning that it had during the recent war.

It's worth stopping by here on the A9 road to see the Victory monument.  It is not surprisingly, but sadly, triumphalist of the government victory in the civil war.  Maybe a few years' reflection would have been wise in order to create a monument with a more conciliatory message...  Across the road is a much more interesting monument and interpretation in memory of a lone soldier who gave his life to protect many others.

The sunset over the waters of the lagoon is just awesome. The sillouhetted palmyrah palm fronds was classically pictorial. Google the sunset time and get there 15mns ahead or you will miss it as it sets v fast.

The water bodies on two sides is unusual and interesting. I was told that you can watch both sunrise and sun set here but did not have time to watch either. It had been a place of interest as far as the military strategists are concerned and articles had been published on Elephant pass in the highly respected Jane;s Defense Weekly on the fratricidal wars in Sri Lanka. The term Elephant pass seems to be a suspect translation of some Tamil or Sinhala term since the terrain does not appear to have anything to do with elephants.
This is located in A9 . Must visit by every sri Lankan. This co-commemorate the  war heroes of the war ended.

This is a place where everyone should pay a visit no matter where you are from. Please pay attention and have good behavior while visiting for this is a place which deserves highest respect. Please remember to talk to a soldier. They are always near the place to guide you through. They will explain the meaning and the importance. Please refrain from taking photos in any manner which can cause disrespect to the monument.
This was a different part of Sri Lanka. Flat, open, dry with very warm winds blowing from the sea. It reminded me more of South Australia than Sri Lanka. The monument is a bit forgettable.

This monument sits by the side of the road  out of Jaffna just before you actually get to Elephants Pass. It's hard to remember that the warfare between the LTTE/ Tamil Tigers and the Sri Lankan government has only been over for 9 years and matters have been resolved but still political issues have to be worked on. But this monument is a reminder that Sri Lanka is one country again and that the army, navy and airforce all played a role in achieving the eventual resolution which pushed the LTTE out. Much of the countryside around the monument has been cleared, to ensure there was no cover for the armies. After heavy bloodshed this is a reminder of the essential nature of peace and unity. It was very busy when we visited due to this being the Sunday of a Poya weekend. 20/30 minutes would be appropriate.

This iconic monument represents the glory of Sri Lankan armed forces. Its built having a few huge bronze hands holding a model of the country, surrounded by bandoleer-wearing lions. This also immortalizes the memories of fierce gun battles fought by our war heroes and the immense sacrifices they have made. Elephant Pass is the bottleneck gateway to Jaffna peninsula which was under LTTE's control since April 2000. This was captured by Sri Lankan armed forces in January 2009, which was a significant milestone of the liberation of the country from the civil war that lasted for 30 years.
Read the history of the area befor you visit.we Found intresting once we know the story of war heros.

Elephant is just 10-15kms away from Jaffna. Elephant pass is well known for its war memorial statue of our great hero Hasalaka Gamini. True hero who sacrifices his life for the nation. Sri lanka Army's one of the main military base.
this a place must visit and see. One of the attraction place to remember the 30 years Civil war . please keep clean this place.
It's a great place to be while you are on the way to Jaffna. There is a war memorial and the surrounding Lagoon is great to watch.

this place has in many ways to dis crib. 01. war memorial statue ( important military base ) 02. sri lankan neack ( in the gateway of Jaffna Peninsula.) 03. one & only place can see sun risen & sun down 04.island's largest salt field ( natual curdle salt from jan-apr temperature)
It’s a very emotional place for Sri Lankans. Built in memory of the 54 th Brigade of the Sri Lanka Army. The entire brigade has sacrificed their lives for the sake of the country.
Show the tanker that was used in the war between the Tamils and the government. It depicts the sacrifice of a soldier to prevent the destruction of a site. Small  area

Many tourists who opt to explore the north are interested in the history and legacy of the war. Crossing from Jaffna to the peninsula through Elephant Pass is the way to begin explore the devastation. We were fortunate to find a terrific guide for that purpose. His name is Mohan and he is a very pleasant and knowledgeable person, with immaculate English and a first-hand experience with the war years, He may be contacted through vishmohan71 at yahoo.com. Highly recommended for those, like us, interested in the details of the conflict and its results, and willing to spend a full long day moving among various relevant sites on the peninsula.
This place is a sobering reminder of the fact that no one wins in war. War has left much destruction, still evidence of bunkers and   few services. Plan your fuel stops in advance.

The memorial to the Sri Lankan soldier is a fantastic monument and designed with great thought. Enjoyed going around the memorial. The station and the JCB that was ultimately destroyed is a reminder of the days gone by.
Finally one country with no war - they call this the Peace Memorial which is very appropriate. Multiple ethnicities finally living in harmony !!

Elephant's Pass is a very important area for the final moments of the war. However, it was very unfortunate that only the winner's side of the story is told at Elephant's Pass. It is very pro-Sri Lankan Army and does not offer another side to the story of the War. It doesn't focus on the struggles of the Tamil minority and Tamil Tiger soldiers who suffered a lot as well.

Went there in the evening and could see the best view of the most narrow part of the country. There was an Army personnel to explain the background of the monument and his speech made us get goose bumps and tears.

From Jaffna we took the train to Elephant pass. This is a great option. As you are at the northern limits of the line you get a seat. It is a hard journey all the way south but we changed to our bus for more comfort beyond this point. The place has an interesting history so give it a try. If you are in a bus you simply pass through!

This strech connects jaffna to the mainland and is worth a visit to view the surroundings.  .  Also to visit the memorial for a very bravel soldier who offered his life to save his comrades during the past civil war

Elephant Pass is effectively a causeway linking the Jaffna peninsular to the south and was fiercely fought over by the LTTE (Tamil Tigers) and Sri Lankan army during the civil war. This history is marked by 2 interesting memorials on opposite sides of the road (but a short distance part). The first (on the left going north on the A9) is a memorial to 26 year old Corporal Gamini Kularathna who had the presence of mind to use grenades to stop the advance of an armour plated bulldozer (present on site) heavily laden with explosives. He gave his own life to save many of his comrades. There is a statue of Gamini with the bulldozer in front and a nearby exhibition space with lots of photographs, personal letters and other documents. Nearby is the recently rebuilt Elephant Pass station. Looking at the timetable, and the interval between trains, it is difficult to see who would actually use the station. All part of the civil war and reconciliation effort. Further up the A9 on the right is a 2nd 'reconciliation' monument which marks the resumption of free movement between north and south. The symbolism of various parts of the monument, including plant species from north and south, is explained in a series of plaques. This is very recent history and it is noticeable that many Sri Lankans are visiting the Jaffna peninsular and a part of their country which for many years was out of bounds. It is a world away from the Cultural Triangle, Hill Country and beautiful beaches but for a complete look at Sri Lanka should not be missed.
The location is nice where you need to go on a lengthy bridge. We travelled in early morning and with the sunset, the horizon was amazing. And the memorial is located in one edge of the bridge.
Major landmark in Sri Lanka. Great place to see. Very beautiful place.  A must-see for anybody. Great history lies here,

On tour way to jafnna you have to pass elephant pass (if you are taking A9 Road which is the main road to jaffna). This has been a strategic location as elephant pass connects jaffna peninsula and the rest of the country. Known to connect thebhead of the Sri Lanka with the body. ( If you see the sri lanka map you would know what this means) There is an army officer who explains everything what happened at thisnplace and how Sri Lanka forces lost and won the place back to tamil tigers. Do not miss there are two locations just by the road to see. Both memorials are of importance. Also the army officer informed the cleanest water in sri lanka can be found here and there are tanks which you can try as well. You can spend about 30minutes to one hour here.

This is a must visit place for all Sri Lankans to remind ourselves of the great sacrifices that were done here to safeguard the country and bring peace to the nation. the war memorial and the memorial honouring Copral Gamini and well kept and maintained .

The entry point to Jaffna peninsula, the key bases of the Sri Lankan army and the place currently holds a memorial statue of a war hero who sacrificed his life to save the camp. Nice peaceful surroundings. A nice place for a quick refreshing stop.

Elephant pass connects Jaffna and the rest of Sri Lanka by just a road and the rest is beautiful calm sea. It is a beautiful sight.  This place holds the monument which was erected with the liberation of the North. It also holds another monument of a young heroic soldier who sacrificed his life to save the entire army camp, by hurling a grenade to a suicide tanker rolling towards the camp., and destroying it.
A monument in the time-honoured tradition of celebrating victories.  Don't waste your time on this, unless you are a fan of pompous war monuments.
this is a significant site in the civil war struggle; it commemorates the bravery of one young soldier, but also brings home the futility of war; quite solemn, quite hot too !

A reminder of three decade war which ravaged the North and the South dividing the Sinhalese fronm the Tamils. This memorial is built to remind us of those heroic forces which unified the country from the clutches of terrorism.
I went  back to see it from Jaffna tuk tuk. Beautiful kept grounds n gardens  saw the statue  had refreshing drink 🍹 in the cafe  beside it

During the war both sides seem to have form for wrecking everything the other lot built including war graves. This monument stands beside the main road and represents the government having the last word. There were no other visitors around when we climbed to the top but a jobsworth still made our driver move the car a few yards.
Great views of the wetlands, and the birds that exist in the area. Great landscape. The memorial is biased, but interesting to note.

Take your time and stop here on your way to Jaffna its right off the highway. From the top of the monument there's a great view over the landscape and remember the lives lost in the devastating civil war not many years ago. Sri Lanka is doing great coming back in it's feet..
this is the land mark for the victory of the war memorial.we all must salute for this.nice place to visit while travelling to jaffna

This place was one of the key bases of the Sri Lankan army and the place currently holds a memorial statue of a war hero who sacrificed his life (Corprol Gamini) to save the camp. The place has documentary of war. This is in the main road it self with very easy access. Since there is not much time to waste to see this, believe this is a must visit place
The beach is not as amazing as it is made  out to be. It is full of debris, rubbish and do not have adequate parking. Nothing compared to beachs in other Asian countries(cleanliness and beauty).
There is a War Memorial and Memorial Statue of Hasalaka Gamini the Copral who wan awarded the Parama Weera Wibushana for his great work done for the Country.
the feeling of visiting this place is speechless I recommend this to every traveler to visit an see it

Elephant Pass Northern Province, Sri Lanka is located in the gateway of Jaffna Peninsula. Elephant pass is the place could be the entrance to the North aria of the country. *.  Elephant Pass has been a strategic military base since 1760, when the Portuguese built a fort, which was later rebuilt and garrisoned by the Dutch in 1776[1] and later by the British. A modern military base was built there in 1952 by the Sri Lankan Army (SLA). At one time, the base and its outlying camps expanded to cover an area 23 Km. (14 mi) long and 8 Km. Since the war ended, when people live in freedom in Sri Lanka, it is fortunate.
very beautiful place. srilankan army won the war in northern. i just thanks to them. this place be in on the way to a9 road.
Covered by the lagoon both the sides and a historical place in Sri Lanka. This place could be the entrance to the North aria of the country.

This is a good place if you're interested in the history of the area. I would suggest googling it before you go and reading up on what happened at Elephant Pass (try to avoid the propaganda takes on it). This location has yet another war monument put up by the Rajapaksa government. I took a bus there and walked across the pass. It's a nice walk, although when I got to the other end it took a while for a bus to come and pick me up so I was left sitting in the hot sun for a while. So maybe just plan it better than I did.
Elephant pass is the point which connects the Jaffna peninsula and the main land. This place you can witness the connection between the Sea and the Lagoon.

A memorial icon that need to be listed as a tourist attraction in Jaffna This is a journey not just of distance, it landscape one to be seen. As the lagoon   cross, the land and  the surrounding vegetation changes trees disappear. palmyrah trees, standing tall. It connects the peninsula to the Sri Lankan mainland.

Elephant Pass has been a strategic military post in the North of Sri Lanka since 1760 when the Portuguese, Dutch and later The British developed military camps in this region. However more recently during the Sri Lankan Civil War (between 1983 - 2009) a memorial to Corporal Gamini Kularatne who advanced the end of the Civil War, by sacrificing his life and single handedly stopping the advance of a reinforced bulldozer tank armed by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam -  Tamil Tigers, which were advancing towards a small group / platoon of the Sri Lankan Army. Suddenly Lance Corporal Kularatne, holding two grenades in his hands, dashed out towards the oncoming bulldozer tank, clambered up the tank's ladder and tossed the two grenades inside it, disregarding the numerous injuries he himself had suffered by then from the bullets of LTTE. Within seconds, fiery bursts of fire accompanied by a series of explosions occurred. Lance Corporal Gamini Kularatne was flung to the ground and lay motionless.  Sadly he died in this act of Heroism. In recognition of his act of gallantry Lance Corporal Gamini Kularatne was promoted to the rank of Corporal posthumously and honored with the award of "Parama Weera Vibhushanaya" on 10 October 1991, the highest gallantry award in Sri Lanka for the first time in the history of Sri Lanka Army. A very interesting part of the history of Sri Lanka that we could have missed but we are pleased that we didn't.

Elephant pass is on the main road from Jaffna to Trincamalee / Kandy so no need to divert, the memorial is a fitting tribute to Corporal Gamini Kularathne who sacrificed his life to save the garrison and is a Sri Lankan national hero.

An important story that seems lost in the big statue and lack of maintenance. The toilets whilst having a large sign are closed and not functioning.  The tank/bulldozer story a few yards away is much more interesting and well displayed
Two war memorials very close together, provide a poignant reminder of past events, with some information about the war.

Enroute Jaffna to Kandy on A9 you would drive pass a painful reminder of the many battles fought here during the Civil War of Sri Lanka, the Elephant Pass. The war memorial was not elaborate though the view of Jaffna lagoon was quite scemic.
Nothing much else there. The drive on the causeway is pretty. The military victory monuments are jarring.

The "war memorial" like most others in the North does not honor the thousands of lives lost in Sri Lanka's most bloody war in history. A painful and distasteful reminder of the futility and glorification of war by the victor. Artistically as well not the greatest piece of work.
It's the only one place in the world you can watch sun rise and sun down (except kanya kumari at india). This is the narrowest place in sri lanka.
Historical place but nothing special to see. We just got a stop there with the taxi on our way from Jaffna to Mullaitivu and Trincomalee by the costal road

I always feel a thrill crossing Elephant Pass. Not sure why, perhaps after reading the book of same name.  Interesting history and well maintained. Cannot enter Jaffna without passing, so, easily done.
Good place of interest, main attraction for locals always willing to chat about there experiences of the war.

this memorial is built to remember all the victims during the civil war. Every item has a meaning and the guiding soldiers are very willing to explain all this to you. It contains beautiful carvings that tell the war-and-peace story in a perfect balanced way. The highest steps are forbidden for tourists. Only the persons who can prove to be related to a war victim are allowed to step up to put flowers, memorial candle or to pray.

An important place in the recent war history of Sri Lanka. Probably polarising, depending on which side you were on during the war. I felt sad for all the lives lost here in the defence of territory, be they Sri Lankan forces or terrorists. Reminders like Elephant Pass are important, so that such terrible wars never happen in Sri Lanka again.
Important place in the map of Sri Lanka, war memories, memorials, has become more historic in the recent times, over the 30 year war in Sri Lanka

If you are traveling to Jaffna on A9, you will pass ElephantPass. On your pass take your time to visit both war monument and the memorial. The morning sunrise is stunning. There is also a mini museum in the memorial with many remaining artifacts of Hasalaka Gamini, the war hero who gave up his life to protect his camp. Also some photos and videos are on display showing the brutality of the civil war that took place in Sri Lanka.

Elephant pass has had its long and bloody history over the course of the Sri Lankan civil war with many brave men killed in action while defending a strip of land which holds the way to the north. It is worth stopping by to look around and you can head on to the war memorial (please be respectful when taking pictures). Elephant pass is essentially a land bridge with the sea all around it with the sun rise and set being clearly visible. I know it sounds odd but try the water from here. the natural filtering in the salty environment gives the water a strangely sweet and refreshing taste.

We can discuss if you like or dislike the monument. It’s not my style, but still we visited it because it’s part of the recent history of Sri Lanka. When you love Sri Lanka, like we do, just stop, visit the monument and think about the pain this island nation has endured. And it’s everybody’s responsibility that it will not occur again, so all the people in Sri Lanka can live in peace.
Stopped at the rest stop for lunch. Pretty basic Sri Lankan food in silver pans. Lots of flies and bloody hot, really appears like no mans land

This narrow bit of land is an amazing place to stop and look around the monuments. To think that this place could have been completely destroyed by Tamil Tiger terrorists.. The reverence the Hsalaka hero is held with is amazing to witness and the gratefulness for him saving the camp can be felt every where around the memorial. Apart from the great significance when defeatign the terrorists, it is also a beautiful area well worth spending some time on your way to the Northern peninsula. It would benefit from improved facililties such as a decent cafe and better toilets.

What a change. This was a strong hold of LTTE, and their defeat by the SriLankan army is written all over with various monuments. The roads and railway tract are back in much better condition. An emotional site to visit
The Elephant Pass is on the road for Jaffna. You would not go there specifically but you would pass on your way to the North.
It was fascinating to see this place which we had only seen in photographs & maps, the roads have been renovated well after the war so it was no problem for travellers.
You need to drive on this narrow piece of land to get to Jaffna.  Its strewn with war memorabilia. Many a battle fought over this narrow isthmus that connects the mainland with jaffna

Sri Lanka's North has many attractions and a quality of its own, in its people, the exotic sea foods and how they prepare the tasty dishes, the hindu and Christian places of worship, the nagadeepa temple, its hospitality. The exciting part is whether you travel by road or by train, this is the isthmus that connects the northern peninsula with all its treasures to the south, a narrow long strip of land traversed by the roadway and rail track side by side.
This logical gate for Jaffna and South this place just the road for many of travellers but how live in Srilanka knows that important this place when the war going

Its a narrow shape land heading to the jaffna peninsula and can see idian ocean from both side of yours.....and its a welknown place for local army camp and battles held with ltte.....now ita almost a place to memories the war hearos and specillay a person who sacrifices his life for others called as hasalaka gamini...... Recently the place developed and more monuments added....recommend to visit any of travellers....

This is the area connecting mainland Sri Lanka, with the Jaffna Peninsula. It is a narrow strip of land with water on both sides. It was an important area when terrorists, used to occupy Jaffna peninsula.
You expect a fabulous pass, but it is just a causeway between lagoons. Nothing special despite the historical significance.
Elephant Pass, in the Northern Province of Sri Lanka is the gateway to Jaffna Peninsula. A9 road and railway line on causeway provide easy access to the Jaffna peninsula.

From the entrance to the memorial everything found has a meaningful description. Starting from the plants on both sides of the memorial. North side of the memorial from the entrance is decorated with plants of North and southern side with southern plants and so on. There will be a solder belonging to Sri Lanka Army, who will brief the tourists with the values and history of elephant pass and the description of the memorial. Further, don't miss to find out about the water well situated near the memorial, which is known as the well which have the best water in Sri Lanka(This was told to us by the Solder who did the briefing)
Just a causeway in a key location. It is the gateway to the north and Jaffna. Little else to say except that there is water on both sides

This is the Lagoon pass crossing the A9 road and the views around this areas is mesmirising. After the completion/rennovation of A9 road the attraction further increased and people do visist this area or even stop while passing through to see the beauties around.

We took the Jaffna train through Elephant pass and it is really nothing but a causeway between two places. It is also the one of the places mentioned in the novel 'the road from elephant pass' written by Nihal de silva who was subsequently killed by a land mine in wilpatu park. The book basically gives both sides of the conflict in sri lanka. But for the average person Elephant pass is nothing special.
This is the entry point  to Jaffna. During the conflict time, it was a critical point for the parties to capture to enter/ defend the Jaffna

I passed Elephantpass on the way to to Jaffna. We stopped at the monument of Corp. Gamini Kularathne from Hassalaka and observed one minute silence to respect him. When he was duty at the centry point of his camp LTTE tried to over run the camp by bringing the huge bulldozer which was covered with bullet proof metal sheaths. When he found that they could not stopped it he ran with grenades and climbed up and blew the driving compartment. He had enough gun fire yet he ran and achieved his target. By this self motivated act without any orders he destroyed this bulldozer there by saved his camp and comrades.  But he paid the supreme sacrifice for the nation. Mother Sri lanka will be always prod of this son and he was first to be honoured with  PARAMA VEERA WIBUSHANA gallantry medal.

Before the conflict started, Elephant Pass is just a Police check point to check the lorries plying between Jaffna peninsula and Colombo. Afterwords Army camp established here. When the war started between Army and LTTE, step by step this camp got bigger and bigger. In 1990's LTTE try to over run this garrison, but army successfully beaten back, killing more than 600 attackers. Undisclosed number of army personal also killed. After that, time to time clashes occurred around this area with casualties. Again in 2000's LTTE made a fierce attack and over run this camp with lost of thousands of lives. Finally in 2009 Army crushed the LTTE and captured back the whole area. Now this bridge symbolically connect the Nothern Jaffna peninsula and the Southern Main land. Recently I travelled through this bridge, then I remember all these! I think every body live in Jaffna peninsula and traveled through Elephant Pass can feel the same.

This is a unique isthmus that joins South Sri Lanka to the Jaffna peninsula. The vast lagoon is on either side.The new Jaffna Railway line runs alongside parallel to the main roadway the A 9. It would be a photographers delight if one is lucky  to capture a picture when a train is crossing the Pass.
We expected more of Elephant Pass but it's just a road through the Jaffna Lagoon. Not spectacular. The only thing you'll see is lots of water and birds.
visited this place and found to have built a commemoration place for Sri lankan Army war heroes. This has been a strategic point for the Sri Lanka army and the monuments there shows the old memories.

The Salt Flats and the causeway - signify the entrance to the Peninsular - and we stopped at the memorial to the Soldier who saved the Camp of 600 by sacrificing his life. The memorial area is well maintained with a  small museum. All worth a visit.

During a 30 year bloody war against ruthless terrorists who killed thousands of civilians in North, East and South there were so many unnamed war heroes. Hasalaka Gamini is one that Sri Lankan know of. He sacrificed his life to  safeguard a major camp during the war. This monument is for him and also many others.
On my way to Jaffna from Colombo on World famous A9 road , i discovered beautiful Elephant Pass. One time there was no access on this route for motor vehicles. But now its 100% free access.

The causeway across the lagoons is the gateway to Jaffna.  It was the scene of heavy fighting to dislodge the LTTE.  There are two war memorials, one at either end.  The northern monument is a general one remembering the fallen government soldiers of this campaign.  Maybe of more interest to the visitor is the one at the southern end as it commemorates a personal story.  Corporal Gamini disabled a heavily armoured bulldozer packed with explosives at the cost of his own life, thereby saving his comrades.  The bulldozer is preserved on site and the statue of Gamini is honoured by a guard of two sentries who stand to attention beside him on a rota with a guard changing ceremony each hour.  Meanwhile his story is told to the visitors over loudspeakers. If you are visiting Jaffna you will pass by these monuments so it is well worth stopping to see some of Sri Lankas recent history.

Elephant Pass is a narrow strip of land which links Jaffna to the rest of the country. It is a wide open space, where there used to be a Fort , destroyed during the war. The road through the Pass is excellent ; the railway line has been rebuilt and will open soon, making the Peninsula even more easily accessible. There are military memorials and monuments along the way, as many important battles were fought in this area. Iranamadu Tank and Chundikulam Bird Sanctuary are nearby. As you approach Jaffna Peninsula, this is a good place to take a break and stretch your legs as the facilities are good.
The causeway is repaired and carpeted and the railway line is also being installed parallel. Just passing the cause way you can see the turnoff the Chundikulam bird sanctuary
Beautiful site. One of the best places in Jaffna to take some photographs. There is a memorial statue for the fallen soldiers.
Unless you read some of the books that describe the things that have happened around the pass it will be not much more than a bridge with a checkpoint.

The Elephant pass is a nice stop on the way to Jaffna. You can visit the Army monument, commemorating the fight against LTTE  taken place there on 2009. A soldier is always available for explanations, if you have a guide who can translate. Nice view of the sea on both sides of the pass.

We travelled with a Sri Lankan driver and car across this area known as Elephant Pass  on our way to Jaffna. Having heard so much about this area during the troubles we were surprised at how the scenery is so very different from how we imagined. Great expanse of sandy areas and then the lagoon on one side and the Bay of Bengal on the other. Sad to think of the loss of life in this area but rejoice that the troubles are now over, However as UK tourists we were more than surprised that near Omantai we had to go through a military check point and produce our pass ports which they photocopied. This in a country that has been finished with war 4years, We also had to get out of our vehicle and produce our passports on leaving the area two days later. Not the most comfortable feeling to get visitors to the North. I don't think that this area can be rated in a way that you can rate a hotel etc, so hence the average rating

Elephant pass is a narrow isthmus joining Jaffna Peninsula to the mainland. It was the biggest salt panes in the country long time back. Portugese followed by Dutch and then British occupied this strategic area and it witnesses several severe episodes of the Sri Lankan civil war. You can see sea on both sides which make you feel that you are travelling on a very long bridge.One can see the railway track being laid which is going to be the rail route for the Yaal Devi train connecting Jaffna with Colombo. A historic landmark of Sri Lanka worth seeing.

This place was one time military strategic place, there was huge military camp situated here, presently there is only a victory monument placed here. It is situated between Vavunia and Jaffna. If you are passing worth a stop. both side of the road you will find sea it has a nice view, it will be nicer after the rail road is constructed.

Great stop off on our way up to Jaffna clean toilets!! Food was fine also. Plenty of people agreed as there were many there.  There were awesome tanks from the recent war full of bullet holes. I think they were call mine explodes, but unsure.

It's a place where you can see the vehicles at the last moment of War between Sri Lanka Army and Terrorists. It's nothing to attract anyone, but you get the feeling of proud to be Sri Lankan. It's very hot in the day time.

This is one of the places which was damaged during the high time of the war. There is a lot of war related literature with "Elephant Pass" as the name.  There is a book named "The Road from Elephant Pass". This area has a salt lake and I think that it is currently not in use. A lot of battles have taken place in this area. Once an LTTE truck had come with explosives with the intention of driving directly into the army camp which was situated at Elephant Pass and one soldier named "Gamini" (who later came to be known with the name of his village as "Hasalaka Gamini) has run towards the truck with explosives in his hand and blasted the truck thereby saving all the lives of the soldiers inside the camp. His pictures, a description of the incident and the remains of the LTTE truck are still there to be seen around this area.

This is the only place in Sri Lanka where you can see the sun rise AND the sun set! It is a thin strip of land connecting the mainland to the Jaffna Peninsula. The road was under construction in fits and starts on the way to Jaffna and a few check points as well. The Pass has been a strategic military base since the 1700s when the Portuguese built the fort. The man made LTTE Terrorist armoured vehicles and the bulldozer that Lance Corporal Gamini Kularathna confronted and blew up with hand grenades, thereby killing himself in the process are displayed in the area.
